ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the different steps that go into developing a biomedical software, such as creating the systems requirement, software design, and validation plan.
Learned more about innovation in tech, how to develop reliable and safe products, and a variety of failed products/designs in tech from not following safety protocols.
Learned about the entire process from the initial idea for a medical software through the regulatory process to implement in clinical settings.
a bit on how the industry works
You will learn about the medical software creation pipeline and all of its nuances.
Learned about medical regulations, and the process of beginning to build a product in the healthcare space.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength is that you get to work with a group of Yalies who share a lot of similar interests. Another strength is that you get to work on a presentation separate from the group project, which you get to learn more about biomedical engineering while working with a new group of people.
Great project course to learn hands-on skills.
Some of the lectures were too detailed about regulatory processes which wasnt always personally interesting.
strengths: prof xp is awesome

The course is split up into two portions: the project and the lectures. The project portion of the class was incredibly engaging - students are put into groups of about four and paired up with mentors to work on a semester long project. You get the chance to engage with a significant medical issue and draft the necessary documents as if you were actually creating medical software. The lecture portion of the class was the provide the necessary information for students to carry out the projects (medical regulations, software design patterns, etc.), however, this portion was not very engaging.

The class was very structured, which helped make each piece of the process much more manageable. 

More guest speakers or even field trips to see exactly how healthcare technologies are used would have been cool.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is super fun and you get to explore a lot of new skills and ideas with a group of friends!
Yes, it was a lot of great fun working with the people in my project group to create a project and help out our advisor.
Yes!
Yes easy to get to know ppl in the class and facilitated great learning experiences. Prof is very interested in learning about the students and trying to get to know their interests.
only if you were really interested in the content. this is not a cs course and doesn't have any serious programming aspect to it.
Yes!
Yes
If you are looking for an low-workload, project based CS/BENG credit, I would definitely recommend this course.
Yep, very solid course overall.
